text: Bottle brought back by a friend. Pours brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of currant, caramel and sweet malt. Malt and berry flavor with some caramel sweetness before a surprisingly semi-dry finish.

Dark reddish brown in color... Aroma of black currents, berries, jammy... Flavor is dark currents, jam, berries, cherries, blackberries, some light caramel and spirit like heat on finish... Enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at Kuhnhenn Warren for the Summer Solstice. The pour is a medium brown, some darker hints shining through. There is a light tan head that falls to a collar leaving a bit of lace. The aroma is. Dry black currant for days. There is just a hint of the actual 5D in here, which is a bummer. Its fruity and sweet, lightly boozy and decent. The flavor is disappointing. Its really thin and dry. The currant is present, but really lacking. The 5D is incredibly thin and leaves a light roastiness. The mouth feel is thin and watery with a light carbonation and a lingering lightly fruity flavor. Light caramel and decent 4D character to it, but its just so messy and light with the addition of currants. Fuck.

Clear thick dark red coffee syrup look. No head. Vibrant berry, bramble, blackcurrants and vimto. Initial taste is lean berry before breaking out in a mulled liquorice, warming booze burn. Finishes sticky sweet dark choc and rich berry. Linger is dank booze and burned off cough syrup. Bottle, Garvies.

Bottle shared at Garvies - thanks to the host. Pours flat amber-brown. Lovely aroma with lots of rich fruits, grapes, berries, some caramel. Big sweet flavor, rich and sugary, with ripe dark fruits, toasted sugars, slight grainy bitterness, some honey, raisin. Full bodied, oily and chewy. Warm finish, sticky, with further caramel, black currants, more honey, grapes, berries. Robust. Good stuff. Novel.
Bottle. Brown with no head. Aroma of blackcurrant. Taste of blackcurrant and licorice, intense. Sweet.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep brown, nose is cherry, blackcurrant, taste is berries, fruity, sweet, syrupy.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours dark red brown with no head. Aromas of cherry, booze, more fruit. Taste is blackcurrant, more booze heat. Like a dry liqueur more than anything.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 [Bottle / 2007 / 6+ years old] Thanks, Mike! Deep brown & prune colored body with hints of ruby & red, absolutely no head on the pour, only a few, small bubbles that rise to the top & immediately pop. Aroma is like chocolate covered berries. Notes of raspberry, currant, & blackberry, all covered in a sweet, candy-like chocolate essence, almost akin to a Tootsie Roll. Back-end notes of red grapes, with burnt toffee & caramel. Taste is very sweet & very hefty, though not particularly boozy considering the ABV. Chocolate candy sweetness, raspberries seem to be jumping out with a mild currant, prune, & grape-y underlayer. Oxidation has taken place just a bit, but not bad for a 6+ year old beer. Very sweet, grows even sweeter with time, & even gets a little bit cloying. The booze is more apparent as well. Still a nice beer, smells amazing, just not exactly something Id seek out. Three ounces was plenty, & even that took a while to get down. Decadent & sweet like the eisbocks, though this one grows somewhat cloying & overly sweet where the eisbocks do not (as much, anyway). A dessert beer, all the way. Split this with people.
Bottle at Mikkeller&Friends. Clear deep dark reddish - no head. Black current. Tartness. Some bitterness. Marmelade notes. Fruity. Acid notes. Marzipan. Light gasolin sharp aroma. Zesty sharpness.

Bottle BrewEngineer. Clear deep copper amber body with cherry notes and no head
Sweet twizzler and cherry aroma with fruit and caramel
Sweet twizzler flavor with raspberry fruit and faint caramel notes
Medium full body low carb

2007 bottle from the cellar and courtesy of a trade long ago. no motion to speak of upon opening bottle and no head whatsoever. aroma is very vinous...port wine like...raisin, dark fruit, alcohol, warm bread...pretty darn good actually. flavor is, well...one of a kind...I went back and forth on this one for a number of sips...one sip it tastes like a combination of alcohol and a soy bomb, and the next Im thinking a good port wine with a strong currant flavor. overall...very boozy ( the 16% shows IMO). lots of dark fruit...raisin, black currant...some soy in the background...interesting, but a very slow sipper. palate is syrupy and no carbonation...glad I got to try it...but not upset there arent more in the cellar...
Pours red.  Notes of sweet raspberries, alcohol.  Flavor is raspberries, booze, sweet malts, and up front cough syrup and medicinally.  Slick and oily smooth.  Not even close to anything good.

Vintage 2007. 6.3 oz. bottle, sent from northernbrews (thanks a lot, Jeff), pours a purplish dark mahogany with zero head. Nose is pleasantly tart with loads of the black currant showing off, some brown sugar and maybe a bit of syrup, though its mostly black currant. Flavour is brutally boozy and cloyingly sweet, with loads of thick, syrupy black currant, cloyingly sweet jam, loads of alcohol and lots of brown sugar. Again, brutally boozy and intensely sweet. At first, I wasnt sure whether to think this was a fun extreme beer or an uber-gross mess of a boozy sweet bomb. The more I drank, the more it became obvious it was the latter. Nasty stuff.

2007 bottle.  Pours a very dark amber color with a small head that quickly fades.  Huge berry and fruit aroma.  Blackberries, raspberries, pineapple, and lots of other tropical and red fruit.  Taste is amazing.  Lots of sweetness but the alcohol helps to mellow it.  Slight alcohol burn in the finish but very smooth.  Thick and slightly syrupy mouthfeel is perfect.  I sipped this small bottle for two hours.  More fruitness comes out as it warms.  Just great.

Old bottle, but not sure how old.  Poured almost still, very deep, garnet-tinted brown.. this actually had some legs to it.  The aroma picked up lots and lots of thick, syrupy currants over smoked black malts, chocolate, and licorice.. peppery alcohol burned the back of the nostrils a little.. this was huge, and I enjoyed it.  The flavor kept the hugeness going.. jammy black currants throughout, with more of the smoked black malts and licorice supporting.. black pepper, blackberry seeds, and more currants around.. finished with tart currants, a touch of smoke, and peppery alcohol.. majorly belly-warming.  Medium-plus bodied and syrupy on the palate with low carbonation.. nicely tangy.. considering the ABV, it held the boozage in check.. overall an excellent brew!

20th November 2009Cloudy brown beer. Resonant blackcurrant nose. Slight dry palate. Rich blackcurrant immediately demands attention. A dry almost Port Wine like mid. Imagine a good vintage Port Wine with just the blackcurrant flavours extracted and that describes this beer well. Pretty one dimensional but its dimension is robust! Fresh blackcurrant,spirity blackcurrant, blackcurrant liquer! Unique beer. Its blackcurrant by the way!

Thanks to ibrew2or3.  Pours rich murky brown.  Aromas of toffee and dark fruit.  Flavor is rich sweet and deep.  Loads of raisin and plum.  Toffe, caramel, and brown sugar as well.  Wonderful sweet treat.

Bottle with Pat, Dallas, and Jimmy. Thanks to james for sharing this awesome brew. Pours a murky brown color, not much head. Aromas and taste of plum wine, apple, brown sugar. Taste was the same with further notes of grape and cocoa powder. So drinkable for the 16%

Bottle split with pat, Dallas and Tom. Pours a deep purple brown body with no head. Aroma is crazy extreme raisin bread and sugary molasses. Mouthfeel is thick as hell with notes of raisin, raisin bread, sour cherry, molasses, sweet bourbon.
Bottle with James pat Vinny and tom. Dark brown pour. Really grape nose. Taste is heavy like an after dinner wine. Alcohol bite with nice dark fruit flavors. Good for the right situation.

Bottle generously given to me for my birthday from BenC...thanks Ben! - Pours dark brown with red highlights and next to no head...just a couple bubbles around the ring. Nose is tons of currant--reminds me of the days of drinking Absolut Kurant in the dorms. Has a menthol component to it as well, and theres a chocolate cake element hanging out below it all. In the end, the currant is a little too strong, too pungent, and too...um...not my thing. Its there boldly in the taste as well, with the same menthol. The malt comes through more as well, big gooey sweetness up front, transitioning to a dry breadiness on the finish. Definitely warms the belly, though the 16.5% isnt too noticeable otherwise. Glad I tried it, but wouldnt seek out.

Bottle shared by Plovmand, thanks buddy. Pours mudbrown with no head. Aroma is blackcurrant, raisins, caramel quite vinous. Flavor is alcohol, blackcurrant, raisins, plums and caramel. Low and soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours almost clear dakr reddish brown with no head. The aroma is sweet cassis, sweet toasted caramel, some anise and has some vinous port like feel to it. The flavour is very sweet and quite boozy with notes of cassis and dark berries. Quite boozy finish. The aroma is good and pleasant but the booze overpowers the overall impression.

Pours a very dark plum color thats completely opaque with a miniscule off-white head that lingers for a minute before disappearing. No lacing. 

Sweet vinous aroma thats bursting with currant, dark cherry, blueberry, grape and other dark berries. This is countered by a nice malt character with hints of chocolate cake, fudge and toffee. Slightly syrupy/medicinal character but not overpowering and although the ABV is really high, there us little to no booze in the nose. Smells like dessert!

Medium bodied with a very prominent vinous, dark fruit flavor thats countered by dark malt notes and boozy sweetness. Lots of sweet currant flavor along with some grape, blackberry, blueberry and other dark berries before being countered by hints of toffee and chocolate cake. Even with the maltier notes its still too sweet for my liking. The ABV is decently masked considering its 15% but there still a decent amount of boozy warmth throughout.

Bottle, shared with javit before the big tasting. Pours murky tawny-garnet, no head, no lacing. Nose is tart berries; raspberries, tootsie-roll, Christmas fudge, cassis coulis, milk chocolate, brandy, tobacco. Lovely smelling stuff, is what Im saying. Flavours of tootsie-roll, cassis, more tart fruit. Alcohol is amazingly absent considering the strength. A monumental brew!

Bottle thanks to FlandersNed. Pours purplish brown. No lacing.  Nose/taste of oak chips soaked in alcohol, black currant, nuts, chocolate and caramel. Finishes with black currant followed by nutty oak chips soaked in alcohol. Medium body.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Courtesy of Secret Summer Santa ]. Unclear medium to dark brown red colour with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, blackcurrant, fruity - berries, alcohol. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet, light acidic and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, blackcurrant, chocolate, alcohol, sharp. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft, finish fee lis light to moderate alcoholic. [20110815]

12oz bottle at pre-GTMW tasting, pours a murky dark brown with no head, aroma was extremely sweet and the flavor had more of a boozy front and finish rather a lot of fruit to it.  Overall this one wasnt my favorite of the night but was still very happy to have tried it.
8/12/11. Bottle shared pre-GTMW. Rich oxidized aroma with plenty of big fruit. A bomb of cassis with plenty of alcohol and a touch of oxidation. I wasnt as thrilled as everyone else tasting it.
Pours reddish brown with no head. Aroma is oak, chocolate and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is vanilla, chocolate, cherries and a bunch of booze. Medium bodied with little carbonation.

12 oz. bottle shared by jckp64- thanks, John! No vintage on the bottle but it seems to be a few years old. The ABV wasnt on the bottle, either, but 16.5% sounds about right. Pours a hazy, murky reddish-brown color with some small tan bubbles around the edge. Aroma of oak, ripe sweet cherries, vanilla, chocolate, earth, and a little booze and oxidation. Flavor of vanilla, toasted sugar, oak, cherries, grass and bitter earth, and warming booze. Really complex. Medium-full bodied, with a sweet, chewy, warming mouthfeel and low carbonation. This one was a lot of fun to drink. Id be curious to try something like this fresh.

This turned out to be a pretty interesting and good beer.  First off, theres a very nice aroma as soon as the bottle is cracked.  Lots of rum soaked raspberries, some blackberry too, with old wood, caramel, chocolate, rubbing alcohol, and plums.  A layered scent with a lot of depth.  The pour is this slightly murky dark brown with a little red in it with a thin head that never full develops before fading away completely.  Nothing at all left on top so no lacing.  This is very smooth going down with some alcohol burn settling in the back of the throat.  But in a good way.  Im surprised how drinkable this is considering how strong it is.  Creamy caramel, chocolate covered fruit (most notably raspberry but maybe even some cherry too), vanilla, and boozy flavors.  This is like a cross between their Raspberry Eisbock and 5th Dementia and I think the best of the bunch.  Well done!

(bottle from Alexsdad06!!).  Pours dark brown with red hue-almost cola color when held up to the light.  Khaki head dissipates quickly even after a vigorous pour.  Lots of carbonation bubbles hug the side of the glass.  Aroma has fruit (cassis), ripe dark pit fruit, and caramel.  Taste is sweet from both the fruit and the malts (caramel flavored), but the malts carry this as the fruit fades.  Full bodied with a slick texture.  Oh so smooth finish with alcohol noticeable, but pleasant.  This is a delicious beer.

Reviewed from notes. Poured into a flute.

Color is a dark reddish-brown with no real head. The aroma slaps my nose silly with really strong fruit components. I get some black currants, cherries, berries, and a pretty nice amount of dark sugars. The taste pretty strong as well with a lot of fruit, and then the booze kicks in a tiny bit, making it a bit less enjoyable than the nose. Feel is great with some nice warming alcohol. Drinks really well and I was actually disappointed I didnt have too much more after my first flute full of this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2010

Bottle thanks to Ryan Meray! 6.3oz bottle poured into my Narke tulip...Pours a really dark mahogany, bordering on eggplant purple. Not surprisingly, no carbonation. Comparing to other Kuhnhenns, specifically KRE, this looks a lot better...Awesome aroma that has a wonderful red grape backbone, freshly squeezed grape juice that I remember sucking down as kid. Complimented by toffee, syrupy molasses and vanilla. A hint of the 15% alcohol creeps in, but its used perfectly to break up the sweetness. Cant imagine a 15%, or beer with fruit smelling better...The taste lets me down ever so much, I think particularly because the alcohol is not as well hidden at all. The grape juice quality is still there but mostly only shows on the front. I get a ton of alcohol not bad grain, but just prevalent. There is a slight tart finish, blackberries are shown off in a great way, sweet but tart. Toffee, vanilla and wood come in too. There is a slight chalky taste and feel that is by biggest complaint, not sure if this has gotten old already!..The feel is warm, chalky and tannic. Slightly distracting...Pretty easy to drink for a 15th. 

Another solid Kuhnhenn, Id drink this again; Id even track it down again.
(thanks thirdeye11) whiskey, pipe smoke, very strong shit.  i might be licking an ashtray.  good lord.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 The beer pours dark amber cognac in color with no head. Wow - the mixture of booze, black currants, berry, and licorice all crowd the nose nicely together. The flavor of malts and berry dominate on a medium body. It is malty syrupy sweet as well.

Bottle. 2007 vintage. Poured into a CCB snifter glass a reddish hued mahagony brown color with a razor thin head that collars around the glass. Just an outstanding nose! The aromas coming from this very fruity from the cassis; raspberry, cherry, apple, orange, pear, apricot - they are all in the nose smelling very sweet. For being 16.5%, I dont get a strong booze note. Medium/heavy mouthfeel with very little carbonation. Ok, the booze is pretty evident in the taste. Lots of fruit notes again in the taste with a deeper dark fruit flavor like raisins and dark cherry, some vanilla as well. The heat from the alcohol warms the mouth, throat, and nostrils. The back end is kind of like cough syrup with the fruit, alcohol, and slightly medicinal/bitter flavor. Overall, this is a beer not for the timid. Big and boozy.

2007 Vintage.  A: The pour is a murky dark amber color with a ring of off-white head forming around the outside of the glass.

S: The nose starts off with with extremely sweet fruits, particularly currants and red grapes. Theres a caramel undertone to the beer as well as some sweet brown sugar and cola.

T: Lots of sweet red grapes, currants, and cherries to keep the sugary fruit character theme. More sweetness from caramel and cola. This one has a weird flavor that comes through as it warms up (maybe cough syrup), perhaps from the alcohol.

M: The body is thick and syrupy, and the beer is fairly lowly carbonated.

D: This was just cloying and got worse the more I drank. Too bad since I really enjoy most Kuhnhenn beers and the raspberry eisbock.

2007 bottle thanks to nellie.  poured a deep ruby with no head.  blackberries, cassis, syrup, and slight vanilla.  thick, syrupy palate, no alcohol, maple syrup, slight cassis, toffee, and caramel.  delicious actually

(12oz bottle 2007 vintage that was brewery aged thanks to Nellie) clear rich brown with orange edges. Nose of sweet caramel, graham cracker, raisins, vanilla, and smooth bourbon. Taste of warming alcohol, cassis berry, graham cracker, toasty caramel, and blackberry jam.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a ruby hue and absolutely no head. Aroma was full of dark sweet grains with a bit of sweet chocolate as well as cherry and raspberry. There was a decent alcohol burn on the nose as well. Flavor had more sweet dark grains with a strong alcohol burn and a bit of dark backing raspberries. A different beer that tasted like Kuhnhenn.

Bottle. Pours a brown amber color with no head. Has a sweet spicy red currant aroma. Sweetish warming malty bitter dark fruit and bitter currant flavor with some weak hints of licorice. Has a sweetish bitter spicy currant finish.
2007 bottle from deyholla. Muddy brownish color no head. Aroma is alcohol, dark cherries, grapes and licorice. Taste very similar with some chocolate notes, very strong. Nice carbonation. Tasty.

Pours a muddy dark brown with no head.  Aroma is chocolate, cherries, and alcohol.  Flavor is lots of dark chocolate and fresh berries, really reminds me of a port wine.  Strong warming alcohol.  Syrupy with virtually no carbonation.

Appearance: Pours like flat Dr. Pepper...kinda brown but kinda burgandy body with no head or lace.

Smell: Wow this smells straight up like Mad Dog 20/20 malt liquor! Dark fruit and booze!!!

Taste: boozy, slight rubbing alcohol quality with a really nice dark cherry and black currant flavor. Perhaps a slightly chocolate note....definitely some toffee.

Mouthfeel: on the heavy side of medium bodied. Fairly slick yet a bit pulpy.

Drinkability: Comes off boozy but its much more drinkable than something comparable like Alpha Kong.

The alcohol is a bit too prominent for my liking. Would be nice to sip on this outdoors in late fall though. Its a nice high octane warmer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2009
12oz bottle. Rating #191. Dark, glowing brown color. Big fruity aroma, sweet and awesome, like red licorice. Whew, big alcohol, like vodka covered fruit, but very tasty. (1249)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Little bottle, 2007. Pours murky, red/brown with no head. Smells big and sweet red fruity with a hint of big, sweet, caramelly, sugary malts. Slight oxidation as well. Tastes of alcohol and dark, super sweet, red fruit. Full, syrupy body with nice carbonation.

12oz bottle shared by bring on BA - thanks, Barry! Now the consensus on this beer is that its very good apparently, but in the immortal words of Bill Lumbergh from "Office Space," "Ummm yeeeah, Im going to have to go ahead and sort of disagree with you there." Its not a bad beer, but there is something a little off with it.

Pours a mostly clear dark brown with purplish hues and a small tannish head.

Aroma is great fresh cassis, spice, and sweet malt. Smells like Id hope it to.

Flavor is a little cough syrup-like but otherwise good. Lots of cassis, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit, and alcohol.

Fairly boozy on the palate with medium body and low carbonation.

Decent stuff, a little underwhelming though. Sort of tough to drink a lot of this.

2007 Vintage. Pours the color of cherry coke - Almost black with a reddish-tinge. No head, but it does sport rich caramel-colored lacing. The fruit aroma hits you as youre still prying the top off the bottle. Sticking your nose into the glass, the rich, dense aromas hit you like a 2 ton heavy thing. Theres nothing subtle here.  Currents, dates, figs, with a hint of chocolate and wisp of alcohol. The taste is jammy, vinous, intensely sweet with a sharp finish.  Very thin mouthfeel, zero carbonation, but crisp and somewhat astringent from the alcohol content.  The 16%-ish rating isnt what hinders drinkablilty so much as the overwhelming sweetness and fruitiness. The slight bitter bite on the finish doesnt make up for how cloying each sip is, and while its a good flavor, it just doesnt do anything for me. This is a good beer, but what I paid for it, I expected superlative.

12oz bottle pours a translucent copper amber.  Aroma is big on the cherries, currants, caramel, grape jelly, a little peppery.  Flavor is the same, pepper jelly, apples, currants, cherries.  Finish is a little spicy.  Could be a bit smoother on the end.

Brow pour, dark in the middle with a thin head.  Very strong, almost syrupy cassis aroma.   Sweet raisin and bubble gum flavor.  Subtle....I was a little drunk when I rated this so Im not quite sure what I meant when I noted that.  Seeing the listing now I am pretty shocked to find its 16.5% alcohol.  It went down pretty easy.

Pours a dark brown with very little head.  Smells like cherry syrup.  The taste is way more balanced than the aroma would lead me to believe, sweet leathery molasses, chocolatey cherry peels, with a touch of bitterness in the finish.  Interesting beer, but then again I dont have many cassissessessess.

2007 bottle.  Murky, near black brown pour with little to no head.  The aroma is strong dark currant with hints of brandy, molasses, fig, wet wood, and pipe tobacco.  The flavor is over-ripe fruit, black currant, cabernet grapes, oak, black pepper, black strap molasses, pipe tobacco, and slight bitter dark chocolate on the finish.  The body is oily, slick and full with moderate carbonation.

Bottle thanks to MatSciGuy.  Pour is dark brownish red with almost no head.  Aroma chocolate, cocoa, light fruit, earthy, and grape jam.  Flavor initially stings the tongue as nice sweet malt and cassis take over.  Also a notable chocolate component with more fruit jam in the finish.  Also a touch of semi-sweet choc. in finish.  Good.  Alcohol not present.

Bottle shared by beernbourbon-  thanks Vince-  really happy to try this.  Pours a dirty murky pond water brown with barely any head.   Notes of caramel, berries, earth, cocoa, and brown sugar.  incredibly smooth.  dangerously drinkable.  this goes down really easy.  16.5% abv?  sheesh.  only the slightest hint of an alcohol burn.  Pretty impressed with this beer.  Interesting offering from kuhnhenn.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2015 Bottle at home ... Huge thanks to a trade (again i forget who. i really should trade less) ... almost black ... deep bluered black... no head ... sweet blackcurrant berry nose very rich ... little vanilla in nose ... huge alcohol presence up front ... lots of vanilla and barley wine tones(ahhh i just read its pedigree above so this makes sence) ... plums and blackcurrent ... nice but not hittinf spot for me... a bit oxidised or something that i cant put words on 3.8
 bottle at home ... deep brown red ... thin lacing .. soft sweet fruits .. massive berry nose ... soft sweet blackcurrant fruits ... juicy fruit .. soft toffee ... dark fruits .. soft toffree roast ... sweet malts fruits ... juicy fruits .. light bitter berry skin4.0

Tasted 1/29/10.  6.3oz bottle.  Mildly hazy with a brownish ruby hue.  Trace head.  Aromas of fruit, toffee and treacle.  Dark berry nuances and sugary fruity candy.  Full bodied with a fruity medicinal flavor.  Hefty amount of alcohol in this one!  Tart and tangy palate.  Nice mix of sugary fruit and high octane.  You definitely pick up on the dark currant note.  Lotta Port and sherry notes.  Wow!

Bottle: &nbsp Dark brown in color, a shade lighter than cola, thin beige head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Huge Cassis nose, some fig/date and a whole ton of Tootsie Roll on the nose. &nbsp Reminds me of their Raspberry Eisbock, to a 

degree. &nbsp Strong Cassis flavor on the tongue, but along with that it reminds me heavily of the Raspberry Eisbock simply because of the Tootsie Roll like flavor. &nbsp Very warming, but not alcoholic, so having said that I would say 

the ABV of 16.5% ABV is very well hidden. &nbsp I am surprised to see that the body and mouthfeel are fairly moderate. &nbsp Again, this beer is warming but not boozy. &nbsp The Tootsie Roll sweetness hides it, much like the Raspberry 

Eisbock. &nbsp I actually like this one better than that one. &nbsp Cassis flavored beers is rare, and this one certainly has some of that flavor associated with it. &nbsp Good beer, warming, lots of Cassis flavor but also some of that 

artificial Tootsie Roll flavor. &nbsp Enjoyable to drink, and it definitely packs a wallop! &nbsp Thanks Chrisdawg for providing me with a one as well as some for Hard Liver!

12oz bottle courtesy of masonjer poured into a snifter.

Pours a hazy reddish brown with a bubbly tan head that shows fair retention and leaves a solid collar and spotty lacing.  There are definitely some boozy legs clinging to the sides.

Whoa, this aroma blew me away!  Just massive currant aroma but with tons of brown sugar, caramel and chocolate.  It smells like a chocolate covered fruit dessert...decadent nose.

The taste is more of the same with the currants dominating with a tart sweetness that lasts from start to finish.  The big sweet sugary malt backbone is more than enough to support the fruit and the finish is almost like a tootsie roll...weird I know.

The mouthfeel is full bodied but with solid carbonation that keeps it from getting cloying or overly syrupy.  The alcohol is definitely there.  Im not sure Id peg it at 15%, but it has a solid burn going down.

Ive been disappointed by a few infected Kuhnhenn bottles, but beers like this are what keep me coming back for more.  If they could get their quality control issues under control, theyd be one of my top breweries without a doubt.  I love this beer.

courtesy of BA trade.
pours reddish dark/ brown, quickly disappearing off white head.
aroma, huge fruit currant nose, hints of caramel.
flavor, loads of dark fruits; currants, chocolate/caramel malts, light fruit tartness that is purely amazing and meshed together wonderfully with the thick caramel palate. Easy sipper, alcohol is well hidden.

Bottled. Burgundy/red coloured. Hazy. Light brown head. Tense aroma of blackcurrent, sweetness and spice. Flavour is full of blackcurrent as well. Alcohol very notable. Spice and blackcurrent in the end. The blackcurrent is totally dominating this. And the alchol as well. Very one dimensional.

deep red, small white head.
aroma is sour, sweet berries, fresh and sharp.
flavor is bitter, fruity, way too bitter, and not sour as in the aroma.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of goryshkewych. Pours a cloudy amber with a small and rough beige head. Extremely intense blackcurrant aroma that becomes almost fat. Medium body, very thick and syrupy sweet blackcurrant notes yet bitter and astringent with some alcohol burn in the finish. 161209

Bottle courtesy of jdub. Pours a wonderful ruby color. Nose is booze, sweet fruits, ripe grapes, wine, dark fruits, plum, raisin. Flavor is an incredible mix of sweet malty caramel, plums, sweet sugary grapes, bitter fruit skins, hot hot booze and dark cherries. AWESOME!

Bottle [6.3oz] courtesy of swoopjones. 2007 vintage. Pours a deep ruby-amber with a spare diminishing fizzy off-white head. That aroma smells weird and awesome at the same time: Lots of dark fruit, and yes, cassis, along with wine grapes and wood. Flavour is quite fruity, with prominent cassis, lightly tart, along with caramel malt, alocohol, some light sugary sweetness, earthy notes and some light hops in the finish. Alcohol for that high an abv is quite well hidden, I was surprised when I saw how high it was. Medium bodied. A unique beer for sure and one that i enjoyed very much. Thanks Mike!

2007 nip bottle thanks to bret27.   Dark brown with just a few bubbles on top.   Super jammy aroma, like putting your head in a black currant jam jar; also some chocolate and light smoke adding complexity.   Very hot flavor, with caramel, wood, and rich berries.   Very sweet and thick, with a sharply alcoholic finish; very low carbonation.   Pleasant dessert sipper but very alcoholic as well.   Pushing the definition of beer, and thankfully put in a small bottle that was plenty for a few people.

6.3 oz bottle, 07 vintage courtesy bret27. Pours a deep ruby with a purplish brown tinge. No head. Aroma is massive red and dark fruits with a... very significant boozy note. Flavor is very curranty with other notes of cherry, blackberry, licorice, chocolate, and alcohol. The booze isnt distracting, theres plenty of sweetness here to cover it up. Thick and liqueur-esque mouthfeel. Would make an epic dessert beer.

Bottle. Dark grape red color with no much head. Aroma has a ton of fruit, dry currants and some grape skin with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is quite smooth for the alcohol content. Dark fruit, sweet and a hint of tartness. Rich and strong, this is a sipper.
pours reddish, purple..no head..aroma of huge currant, alcohol, and medicine..flavor is very similar with added cranberry and figs..powerful, unique, and fantastic

Bottle from Lothore: "my heeero!"  Smells like cranbluraspberrygrapes - as thick and actually fruity as a home-reduced compote.  Color is an even brown with hints of red.  Flavor is an aged blackberry brandy with berries floating in it - I once had a very similar flavor experience at the Green Mill in Chicago where said brandy has been cut with grapefruit juice.  This beer boats pure fruitiness, thick tannin and a base of chocolate.  Yet more proof that these guys make the best big fruit beers on earth.
Thanks to dmschefke. This is something. Fruity/cherry with intense caramel. Maybe some raspberry. High alcohol. Not cough syrup, but intense.  Little carbonation. 2007 bottle.

12 oz. bottle I received in a trade some time ago.  Pours a clear mahogany color with a thin off white head.  Very light carbonation.  Has an odd medicinal berry aroma.  It tastes like cherry cough syrup.  This stuff really coats the tongue.  There is some alcohol in this one.  Not a real fan of this beer, but glad I had the opportunity to try it.

187ml Bottle:  Aroma of raspberry, currant, light alcohol, light chocolate, and a hint of burnt caramel.  Poured magenta/purple/brown in color with a tiny, beige head that disappeared but lasted around the edges.  Cloudy.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of currant, chocolate, slight wood, slight tobacco, and light alcohol.  Light to medium body.  Thin, slightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Currant, chocolate, and alcohol finish is slight dry.  Alcohol is quite hot.

Bottle (170ml).  via trade with Glouglouburp - shared with garthicus.  Deep, slightly hazy brick-red, small frothy off-white head.  Moderately boozy but nutty, lush aroma, sour "dark" fruit for days, cocoa - wine grape skins, really appealing.  Taste - wow, thats strong - like a roasty schwarzenwald torte with extra kirsch - good, nutty and chocolately, but very strong.  Slick, oily and boozy mouthfeel, long alcoholic and sour fruit finish.  Damn I like it, but I almost felt it might be better poured over french vanilla ice cream.

Thanks to HogTownHarry for sharing. Appearance: port red with zero head. Aroma: Lots of raisins and malt, so much oak and vanilla and deep musk & spice. Flavour: woah! Booze, raspberries, wood, malt, cherry, chocolate, tart and spicey. Just so much going on. Terrific liquor finish.

800th Rating - 2007 Bottle - Thanks dmschefke!  Pours a beautiful transparent but vicsous reddish amber, ring of tan head...aroma is amazing, dark currants, booze, strawberry...flavour is a bit different, hard to taste as I just burnt off the top layer of my mouthskin, this bitch is hot...second sip is a bit more open, maybe its from all my newly exposed tastebuds, cherry, cocoa, dark berry...a bit antiseptic like a cough syrup, but with a nicely tart finish...def not a beer...

6oz bottle. Pours a dark reddish color with a very miniscule clearish head. Nose is currant and grapes with a light sweetness to it. Palate is filmy and smooth. Flavors of grapes and dates with some fig notes almost.

2007 187 ml bottle.  Rich black courant aroma, dark cherries, dark fruits, with rich decadent malts in the background, molasses and caramel.  Pours a dark reddish brown, no head.  Very rich, molasses and heavy caramel malts with rich dark fruits, black currants, black cherries, rich strawberries, very rich but very smooth.  Very decadent.

Cbkshubert shared this one with me. Good dose of fruit on the nose. Red mahagony body with little oto no head. Thick brew wit good mix of blackberry and cranberries and some spice in the mix. Heavy on the palate but good brew thanks Craig.

on tap at brew kettle - Very cloudy dusty brown color with medium sized tan head. Aroma has tons of light caramel, red grapes, toasted oak, vanilla bean, with fairly notable currants. Flavor is malty, with toasted caramel, oak, vanilla, dates, plums, fair amount of currants, slightly acidic, notes of maple syrup. Finish is drier than I would have expected, with a balancing bitterness.

Thanks After4ever! Pours cloudy reddish amber with an off-white ring of foam. Huge cassis nose... seems like straight cassis. Light body and carbonation. Sweet cassis/berry/toffee taste. A little hot, leaves an impression of berry liqueur rather than fruit beer.

Wow.  Thanks to Hoppymeal for this one.  2007 vintage.  Pours a thick dark brown with very little head.  Aroma is strong with currants, chocolate and alcohol.  The flavor is also very strong with the fruits and alcohol with some dark chocolate.  Very warming as it goes down.  Very good, but not easy drinking.

2007 bottle.  Pours of dark brown with a slight off-white head.  This is one crazy beer!  Strong penetrating cassis aroma with a hint of raspberry and perhaps some oxidation.  Flavor is more of the same, with a powerful liqueur characteristic.  The alcohol is certainly there at the finish, although it is not completely out of control (although I could not have finished a bottle without help).  A very interesting creation.
Bottle of the 2007.  Aroma is liqueur-like, cassis and cocoa.  Brownish red with a thin head.  Strong, fruity and boozy flavor.  Really more like a liqueur than a beer.

cola brown pour with no head.  Aroma was up front celery and brown sugar.  Flavor was up front alcohol,  maple syrup,  dark fruit,  and cherry.  You can easily pick up the 16.5 in the finish.  good for sipping a small sample

7-oz, waxed. Thanks, Pantanap! Pours a cloudy dark brown with bright caramel highlights. Looks sticky, viscous, and oily, before you even pick up the glass. Huge sweet and syrupy nose. Maple, marshmallow, caramel, chocolate, and black currant nose. Sticky thick oily body, totally mouth-coating. Rich, roasty, cloying, ultra-boozy, super-intense...and still very delicious and fun to drink. Makes you a little sleepy, though, even after just an ounce or two.
Bottle (Mini) at Kuhnhenn. Huge berry/ cassis aroma. 16.5%%%%Boozy!!! Intense black berry. Did I say boozy? Luller syrupy wine like mouthfeel. strange

12oz hand bottle from Douglas88.  Pours dark brown with some red hues, near non-existent head.   Aromas of dark fruits, raspberries, cherry, some alcohol, light caramel, and a strange sort of medicinal characteristic going on.  Flavors are caramel, fruits, and alcohol.  It isn;t overwhelmingly hot, but the booze is definitely there.  Light carbonation, makes for a smooth but not quite rich mouth feel.  Thanks again Douglas, you rock!

On tap at The Brew Kettle in Strongsville, OH during "Ogre Fest 2009" (early February).  They sent an employee up to Michigan to fill their kegs.  Perhaps the most syrupy and thick beer I have had in a long time.  The Raspberry flavor is overpowering, so much so that we had a tough time downing the 3 oz taster glass that we ordered.  This beer is so powerful it will knock you out in short order.  Worth a try to say that you have tried it!

A rare treat enjoyed twice at the Winter MI Beer Fest 09.  Huge fruit and alcohol are all through this monster of a beer,  but instead of balancing eachother out, there both really up front about it.  The more i drank the more i liked, and wish i could find this again in a bottle.

On tap at the Brew Kettle.  Pours dark red with no head.  Has a wonderful aroma showcasing dark fruit.  Maybe some raspberry.  Mouthfeel is medium.  Taste was no good.  Robitussin comes to mind.  I could barely choke down half the glass.  Im wishing I could get my money back.

Pours a deep rusty brown color with thin off white head.  Aroma is of red licorice, alcohol, and some cough medicine.   Taste is red licorice, currants, alcohol and cough medicine.  Its a tad abrasive, but at the alcohol level its expected.  It seems like it could use some sour backbone to balance out the fruit.

Thanks to alexsdad06 for this!  2007 bottle.  Pours a murky reddish brown with no head.  Aroma is alcohol and red licorice (good choice, bro), and black currants.  Taste is caramel malt, black currants, and alcohol.  It is thick like cough syrup.  A good sipper.

Thanks to Bobby91w for this bottle.  I didnt realize it was a 16.5% brew, good thing it is a small bottle.  Pours dark with thin head.  Aroma of blackberries and currant, caramel, and oak.  Very sweet, but very good currant flavor.  Solid brew, my first try of any of their beer.

December 07 vintage, aged about 14 months in the bottle.  Pours a dark and murky mauve color with hints of plum.  A minimal, fizzy, off-white head dissipates completely, and rather quickly.  Dense, sugary sheeting slowly glides down the glass.  The aroma is quite potent, showing more like a liquor than a beer.  Massive amounts of sweet and tangy cassis dominate the underlying fig and plum notes.  It takes a real effort, but I can extract some brown sugar malts, along with a good bit of ripe red grape and vanilla laden oak.  The flavor follows suit, a ridiculous amount of cassis and dark fruity sweetness crushing everything in its path.  Oak and vanilla rush in to fill the void that the avalanche of fruit leaves behind, but are again quickly taken over by an aftertase reminiscent of the filling of a Fig Newton.  Quite boozy and somewhat medicinal, the ample sweetness saves this one from being unbearably hot.  Thick and syrupy in the mouth, with very little carbonation, the palate suits the beer but still doesnt do much for me.  I can appreciate this, but it really just isnt my style.

Deep brown in colour with a thin tan coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma all cassis with lots of blackberries and blueberries, honey, noticeable alcohol but never overpowers the berries.  The flavour is was incredibly smooth for such a large beer, very sweet, noticeable alcohol, lots of cassis.  Warming mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes quite warm with a high sweetness.
This was balanced incredibly.  Neither the alcohol nor the sweetness took over this beer leaving you with lots of fruit to enjoy.
Bottle at Mondial 2008, Montreal, Quebec.
Sampled on May 29, 2008.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 Thanks ogglethorp.  I anticipated this beer, but did not know what I was getting into.  Pours a very murky brown with no head.  Aroma blends berries with wood, caramel, and significant dose of alcohol.  In the mouth, theres a lot of dry, resinous, woody elements at first, competing with and not really harmonized with a strong, nearly cloying fruit syrupy component.  Kind of a mess.  Comes together in a floral, bittersweet finish.  Overt alcohol presence through it all.  Thick body, tannic palate with slight effervescence and significant warming.

Thanks to polomagnifico for the bottle! 07 bottle. Dark murky red-brown body, nice hues. Beige head becomes a ring in seconds. Nose is slightly tart with lots of current and cherries, vinegar... vaguely reminiscent of Earthmonk without the varied and full blown-Flemish qualities or complexities, more desert-like and sweet-dominant. Flavor is very syrupy and fruity, but the alcohol takes control, leaving a desert finish reminiscent of fruity, cakey brownies. Thin body which doesnt support the beer, quite warming. I like KTC, but it was a smart decision to bottle this in 6.3oz doses.

This poured a nice bluberry blue color with no head at all. Aroma was mainly currants and alcohol. Flavor was extremely sweet and ncie and fruity currants. Finish was really warm and pleasant. Great stuff.

Handbottle at Tronraners Xmas Eve^3 tasting.  Very dark brown rust color with nearly no head.  Overwhelmed by aroma and flavor of black currant.  Amazing fruity flavor and syrupy body with hints of anise.  Very pleasant warming sensation.

Bottle from jsquire, thanks man!  Dark reddish/brown pour.  Aroma is very, very sweet.  I get a huge hint of port wine, liquid raisins, honey, maple and fruit.  Flavor is very sweet.  Hints of maple, honey, and big time doses booze that have had raisins soaking in it for a week.  I actually prefer this to the KRE...this was a very nice after dinner drink...VERY nice.

Deeep black red brown color, no head at all.  Huge aroma, cranberry/currants, sweet malt, tons of booze.  Currants hit you in the first sip, some brown sugar, with lots and lots of boozy warmth.  Palate is thick and sweet.   Aftertaste is tangy and brandy booze.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD! Pours a deep, dark reddish-brown with no real head. Big sticky-sweet aroma of malt, black currants, sugar, and alcohol. Tons of black currants in the taste, with malt, molasses, and a sharp, alcohol bite. Lingering fruity sweetness and alcohol sharpness. Very different and very strong.

Bottle thanks to hopscotch. Pours with a small slowly rising light brown head that never appears again. Murky very deep red to brown body. Alcohol legs, but no lace. Aroma of brown sugar, maple, cassis and a ton of different berries I couldn’t even begin to list. Some alcohol too. Taste is alcohol, brown sugar and berries. It doesn’t burn, but there is a medical taste. Similar to DFH Fort. Yeasty aftertaste. Very syrupy, light carbonation.

Thanks JCB for sharing. The pour is murky purple brown with no head. The nose is very pungent, fruity, berry jam, mild spice, warming alcohol. The flavor is very very strong and rich berry, sweet, spicy, warming alcohol, woody. Very very interesting beer. Thick on the mouth but doesn’t show the alcohol as much as one would expect.

12oz bottle from my Secret Santa - thanks, Anwar!!! A dark, viscous pour, cloudy and still almost like some guy in the corner of a darkened bar waiting for a fight. Massive blackberry nose, lively and appealing. Palate is a bit prickly, like that dude trying to get a rise out of you, but the booze is not majorly face-shredding. Bitter syrup and wood in the finish, I dug this one.

Bottle generously shared by JCB. No head on a reddish brown pour. Cloudy.  Smells and tastes like jellied blackberry candy.  Quite sweet, but also earthy, woody, and a bit perfumy. A slight tingle on the palate. Complex yet surprisingly drinkable given the ABV.
Thanks to JCB for sharing!  Hazy orange pour.  Blackberry aroma.  Sweet fruity flavor and the alcohol is EXTREMELY well masked.   Very special treat!

tronraners Xmas Eve Eve Eve Tasting. Sample from a handbottle thanks to tronraner.  Reddish brown with a thin spattering of white carbonation.  Big black currant and alcohol aroma.  Taste is huge warmth and currant fruitiness with a big alcohol finish.  This was amazing and reminded me a lot of a Cassis version of DFHs Fort.

Handbottle courtesy of douglas88, shared at Xmas Eve Eve Eve. Pours a dark rust orange with small beige head. The aroma is strong black currant, various other berries, malty chocolate, and some alcohol burn. The flavor is equally as heavy on the black currant as the nose, with some ashy wood, candyish sweetness, and brandy. The finish has a strange, but not unpleasant, chalky bitter chocolate quality. Can definitely feel the alcohol, but not so much taste it. Wow, this is a powerful sipping beer. Not something I would want a whole lot of, though.
Hand bottle shared by tronraner at his Christmas tasting. Dark brown with practically no head. Aroma of raisins and cherry liqueur. Flavor is the same. Medium bodied, smooth and alcohol-dry.

Wow, this stuff smells great. Very fruity, with Blackberry and black currant and a lot of berry-type smells mixed in. Flavor is pretty what youd expect, with some coffee notes mixed in for good measure. Some rich tobacco notes, too. Dryish red winey finish. Really good. Hand bottle from tronraner at the Maryville tasting.
Old rating. Very fruity and berry aroma to it. Sweet overall. Light reddish color with a small head. Flavor was very medicinal though and reminded me of benadryl. Tough to drink all of this.

Draft many times.  Pours a mahogany body with a thin white lacing.  Big fruity alcohol flavor currants, berries, and man just like an awesome flavored vodka with some malty caramel.  Interesting beer, you cant miss the 16%.

This was cloudy and a mixture of purple, garnet and brown in color.  The nose showed off the fresh cassis along with a funky barnyard mixture.  In the mouth it was like Tyson in a glass packing a huge punch.  It was concentrated and flavorful albeit a bit simple.  This hides is alcohol fairly well and drank much better than the Kuhnhenn Imperial Stouts on this night.

6oz serving in small snifter at brewery.  Pours reddish mahogany with tan head. Looks like a barley wine. Aroma is strong with currants and licorice with sweet malt and caramel. Flavor is  dominated by currants and licorice. Finishes sweet and boozy. Too sweet for me. First couple of sips were great but 6oz was almost to much as it was way to sweet at the end.

Bottled, thanks Marsblursi!  Hazy mahogany colour, minimal head. Rich aroma of black currant surbet and alcohol. Very sweet with loads of estery black currant. Some cramel lures underneath until cranbery vodka strikes and ruine the party. Finishes with vodka, mango and dextrose. Never tasted anything like this before...

(Bottle thanks to hopscotch) Pours mahogany brown with some red hint. The flavour is of perfume-like red and black currant with a syrupy/toffee-like malt sweetness. Some raspberries is also present. Still quite clean. The flavour is of currant and raspberries with notes of syrup and alcohol. The mouthfeel is syrupy and light to medium carbonated. A alcohol dry finish.  Medium to full bodied.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2008 Draft at brewery 10-28-08, 6 oz. served in a small brandy snifter, I let the ale warm up a bit before sampling, served dark reddish brown with some black edges, arrived with a creamy tan head that lasted a while, head deflated to a small ring, no lacings on the glass but has some legs, aroma of dark berries and more berries, berry candy, dark candy sweetness and dark / burnt caramel, some licorice and earthy fragrances, aroma is reminiscence of a fruit and berry brandy or liquor, flavor  of dark berries and heavy malt sweetness, some alcohol flavor but it is felt more then tasted, wow - alcohol warms the throat big time and sends a big tingle up the nostrils, I think the alcohol is hidden well for a 16.5% ale, mouth feel is heavy and thick, coats the palate and throat with each sip and then some, almost has the soothing feel of cough medicine without that much alcohol taste but the alcohol feel and oozing into the pores of my throat is there, the big alcohol and fruit and berry flavors sort of give the impression that this ale is similar to a cough syrup, anyway, this certainly is a Winter sipping / Warming ale, if you like a full mouth feel and thick coating drink this is it!

Bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a deep brown color with some red highlights and a thin beige head that faded to a ring.  Overpowering aroma of manure, some sweet raspberry, and a hint of caramel.  Smooth, lightly fruity entry leads into a moderate caramel maltiness with some more of that awesome manure that leads into a boozy raspberry finish.  Low carbonation, slick and full on the palate.  I don’t get where the shit smell/taste came from, but it ruined an otherwise nice beer.

Basically a dark muddy brown color with a thin, quickly diminishing foam.  Light wafting reveals some nice aromas of black currant, chocolate, toffee and red licorice, but a strong sniff reveals an awful core of medicinal qualities, like a trip to the pharmacy and a big whiff of antibiotics.  Flavor is too fruity and too sweet.  I feel like there is a great tasting beer underneath the overly fruity, overly sweet, medicinal mess.  There is some very tasty notes of dessert-like malts, but overall, tastes like a handful of pills and sugary sweet black currants.  Disappointed.  Had higher hopes.

Thanks to RagallachMC for the bottle. Hazy mahogany color with a medium head. It smelled like a high ABV wine, loaded with dark fruit (currents and plums) and a little vinegar. Tasted the fruit first and foremost, followed by a malty/earthy heaviness. Sticky texture with a lot of alcohol. But it gets some points for the uniqueness.  Its definitely a sipper. They should have used their small rasperry eisbock bottles on this. I opened this bottle with nobody to share it with (except the fruit-flies that its attracting).

12oz bottle shared by iowaherkeye. Poured a clear garnet brown color with a light tan head. Smelled distinctly of berry juice and raw alcohol. Like a fruit liqueur. Medium to full bodied and sweet with a big warming alcohol effect and lots of berries (especially raspberry). Syrupy in a cough medicine kind of way. A berry flavored cought medicine, if you will. A bit much, but interesting.

Bottle thats to hopscotch at home with mesandsim. Alround rating: Alcohol, blackcurrents and loads and loads of rubbing alcohol, its just soo big and over powering that its hard to get much else. We shared this between the 3 of us and no one finished thier glass, it was like the strongest cheap european lager ever made with a bottle of cassis added and it was really bad. Even at the end of the night when everyone had gone and i was like just something to put me to sleep, i poured this down the drain.

I cannot believe I haven’t rated this yet I have had sevarl bottle and on tap many times. This is one of the beers I like to have for that after dinner drink. poured dark brown mixed with some purple with a small tan head. aroma all that is good in a sweet beer, currents and other berries some caramel andwith a nice alcohol kick  flavor sweet beeries. those currents and alcohol.

Dark brown pour with minimal head. The aroma is in your face apple juice and pear, berry, and tons and tons of booze. Yikes. Sweet, soggy, wet cardboard flavor, very tough to drink and incredibly sweet. Kind of makes me feel sick. I’ll be using the rest of this to cook. I liked it better when I had it on tap, no doubt.

RBSG 2008. Interesting, seemed to work, but not what I was expecting. Sweeter body, chocolate and caramel flavor up front. The cassis flavor blends in, adding another layer of flavor. Everything compliments each other nicely, but a tad overly-sweet.

GTMW 08 - This is another example why Kuhnhenn was one of the tops at the fest.  Poured hazy cloudy brown with a large tan head.  The aroma has lots of black currant, smooth rich caramel malt ~ quite dry and nice.  Rich sticky body with lots of smoothness to the carbonation.  The flavor starts with cassis with some pith, smooth caramel and lots of alcohol presence, but it seems fitting for the beer and doesn’t overrun the other flavors.  The finish is hot, but it works for it still and then there is a lingering dryness with the fruit.  Great fruit beer.

A Mes rate: bottle thanks to our Magic.Thick and hazy red brown with absolutely no chance of it holding on to a head. So, so , SO much cassis it’s almost like pop. Completely over the top. Way too much soy and black currant. Sickly and painful, blackcurrant cordial concentrate and massively boozy obviously. Probably a hard work beer to make but it’s just too much to drink. The only good thing is that this could get me really really drunk.
Much too fierce and stinging alcohol burn on the palate. Pretty awful to be honest.

Tasted at RBSG ’08 and from a bottle that wetherel generously left at the PP Bottle Shop. Clear brown with no head and a bit of carbonation. Huge cassis aroma that mimicks clove, mint leaf and potpourri. Some caramel malt underneath. Sweet and fruity that finishes with a strong phenolic cassis and hot alcohol blast. A bit stingy on the palate. Very unique, medium drinkability. Gets the points for intrigue.

12oz bottle from iowaherkeye.  Thanks Joey.  Tried at PP bottle shop with Brad.  Little head.  Deep red amber color.  Lots of fruity casis aroma.  The smell blows you away.  Very sweet.  A hint of oxidation that’s hard to notice under all that other aroma.  Some alcohol burn when you taste it.  Sweet.  Good, but not very drinkable, probably because of the high ABV.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 Tap GTMW 2008
Berry, black and red sweetness in the aroma.  
Tastes very, very sweet and cloying with more berry.  
Definitely a little boozy, and this beer is flawed, dont get me wrong.  
Lots of alcohols in this, very cloying.
However, the taste and mouthfeel in this are amazing.  8282008
--re-rate---
bottle 2007, consumed 9/13/2009

Aromas of cassis, bright red fruit, port, cocoa, alcohol.  Wow.
Taste is a lot of leather, port, red fruit, higher alcohols.
Finish burns a bit, cloyingly sweet.
This is a sipper, but a nice one.
Bitterness comes in at the end.
10/4/7/4/17

Very boozy, very thick.  Heavy sweetness, like thick sweet blackberries.  Hard to drink a whole lot of this, but its packed with flavor.  Heavy on the sweet berries.  Very dark fruitiness to it.  Complaints: too sweet, to syrupy.

[1401-20080530] Bottle. Sweet berry roast malt aroma is heavy. Clear, dark brown red-hued body with a long-lasting foamy yellow tan head. Boozy black berry cordial flavour is mixed with something malty and roasted. Medium body is a little boozy. Really interesting concoction, good berryness.
(0T @ Mondial; Montreal, QC)

UPDATED: APR 24, 2009 at RBSG, I remember this one being sweet and chocolate to go with the fruit influences. RERATE- Thanks to Cloudskipper, definite Port influence and a ton of fruit and vinous influences.

Thanks to MikeTD for hooking this up. Cracking open the bottle fills the room with a wonderful sweet berry aroma. The aroma in the glass is more chocolate and tangy berry, very nice. The aroma just keeps you there, taking your time sipping. Very dominant chocolate taste that is complimented by the berry. This is a delicious desert beer and just a hair behind its cousin raspberry eisbock. Absolutely wonderful.

In short: Some kind of extra-sweet and extra-alcoholised fruit beer concentrate.  Gross.
How: Tap at brewpub
The look: Murky brow body topped by a large tan head
In long: What an odd beer this is, and I use the word beer in a very loose way.  Flavours were an overload of cassis, an extreme sugary sweetness, some sort of chemical/mercurochrome flavour, a light milk-chocolate tastes,  cough syrup, strong alcohol presence, extra-sweet jam and fruit flavours more reminiscent of fruits concentrate than fresh fruits.  Overall this felt like short of cheap hard-liquor in a glass of cheap extra-sweet fruit beer.  That beer is tenacious indeed, my cousin Louis can be tenacious too with girls, and theyre both gross.
Draft at Hop Devil Grill: pours a dark reddish brown, sweet aroma, taste was sweet with dark fruit and licorice,  I really enjoyed this one.

on tap at hop devil in manhattan.  it was happy hour - so we got this half price at the same time as Kuhnhenn Rasberry Eisbock... which was a lot to take all at once.  pours deep brown with thin tan head.  aroma of cherry, perfume and light caramel.  strong fruity sweetness undercut with sour tartness.  prune also.  only a little of the alcohol shows.  long slightly dry bitter finish.  contrary to popular opinion, I actually liked this a bit better than the raspberry eisbock.  wacky stuff.  just too sweet for me overall.  K-6

Sample, savoured at the Mondial de la bière on May 30 2008; eye: burgundy, tiny ring of beige head, clear, no effervescence; nose: concentrated black currant, powerful, candied fruits, molasses, liquorice; mouth: black currant, molasses, soya sauce, malt, liquorice, finale in concentrated black currant with soya sauce, rather sweet, not much carbonation, full body, bubbling on the tip of the tongue; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, savourée au Mondial de la bière le 30 mai 2008; oeil : bourgogne, petit anneau de mousse beige, claire, pas deffervescence; nez : cassis concentré, puissant, fruits confits, mélasse, réglisse; bouche : cassis, mélasse, sauce soya, malt, réglisse, finale en cassis concentré avec sauce soya, plutôt sucré, peu carbonatée, corsée, pétillement sulbout dla langue; en résumé : pas mal bon

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle.  Muddy mahogany hue.  Bursting currants over a sandy cookie dough aroma; toasty, alcoholic, and framed in an odd, dirty, vine-and-stem kind of fruit character.  Flavor is a burnt caramel and raspberry cough syrup oppressive searing sweetness.  Currant liqueur.  A sparkling, alcoholic chocolate touch tempering it lightly.  Hazelnut skin bitterness; too weak to make impact against the wash of sugar, which is monolithic in intense, rum-like, hot cane sweetness.  Full body is hot and waxy; sticky sweetness fattening up and bearing down as warmth affects it, finishing on honey, heat, and syrupy fruit, and dried out with alcohol.

Never a contemplative form of port-like digestif sweetness in this currant and caramel liquor; rather, a rushed, overripe, reckless sugar character that, when not unbearably cloying, tends to be medicinal and sharp, though alcohol never seems too bullyish.  Its just that all that sugar seems so bombastic, and seemingly for its own sake.  Thanks Mike!

(bottle, thanks Stine?!) This one was on the wants list, but no more.  Pours a really thick reddish-brown with just a scant off-white head that disappears quickly.  The aroma is decent enough, with melted raspberry popsicle, caramel, and chocolate.  This is very sweet, but theres also a lot of alcohol lurking in the background.  Warming reveals more raisin characteristic, like a port wine, along with some brown sugar.  The taste is a different story.  Its a really syrupy, sugary, fruity, boozy mess.  The main tastes are cherry/raspberry and brown sugar.  The alcohol that was lurking in the background of the aroma, now steps to the forefront and unleashes its sharp stinging character.  The palate is really sticky and stings with booze.  This is definitely over the top.

12oz bottle. Huh... interesting beer. Aroma of grape cough syrup with some cola spritziness. Welches grape  soda with some grain alcohol thrown in for good  measure. Behind all that sticky, boozy aroma some tart grape skin dares to peek its head out. Pours a decent looking thick brown/purple with rich mahogany highlights. Flavor was... booze.  Lacking nuance. Alcoholic grape soda with  a cough syrup like stickiness. Holy shit this is sweet, cloying and boozy. Thick, sticky, hot and boozy on the tongue with a tart grape stem finish. Damn. Too much. Thanks Eben?

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2008 On tap at Kuhnhenn.  Wow.  Poured a deep purple, with a creamy off-white head.  Left fair lacing that mostly diminished.  Aroma was amazing, with raspberries, currant, sweet malt, and brown sugar.  Taste was heavily sweet, and body was syrupy.  Cant drink a lot of this, but is a delicious sipper.  I liked it better than Kuhnhenns Raspberry Eisbock.

Bottle courtesy CigarCityBrew. Thanks a bunch Joe for the best beer of the night. Pours a clear amber with a small light tan head. Aroma of black current, raspberries, sweet malt, and caramel. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and undetectable alcohol. This is the best screw up ever. Damn good.

Objectively speaking:
Another Kuhnhenn fruit beer that is absolutely all that the Raspberry eisbock is not.

I like:
I really wanted to like it, but this was insufferable to me.

I dislike:
Unjustified syrupyness because the complexity is very limited. Hardcore leathery notes veer towards astringence. Rough cheap milk chocolate sickening sweetness. Cough syrup abundance. Somebody must have stepped on those currants with dirty shoes.

2008-05-30. Ruby tinged dark brown body refuses to give up a renewed head. (3+) Massive fruity aroma, tart notes to cassis - blackberry - grape notes. Flavour is similarly quite fruity, warming alcohol shows itself more in the throat than on the tongue. Cassis and generic fruit character are the dominant flavours, pleasant up front but finishes with a bit of a twist that I do not care for. Malt in the background has a light tang - reminiscent of their Raspberry Eisbock, or at least my memory of it. (7+) Smooth medium bodied palate. (3+) Decent and I have rated it well but I am not sure it is one I would return to. Bottle, Mondial, Montreal, courtesy of Tuqueboy

Verre de 4 oz, dune bouteille au Mondial 08. Arômes envoûtants de liqueur de cassis et de caramel. Robe brune au reflets rouges, légèrement trouble. Très sucrée et fruitée en bouche, le cassis est omniprésent et est accompagné par le caramel et le chocolat. Finale marquée par lalcool, qui demeure bien dissimulé pour une bière aussi forte. Une bière très sucrée, à siroter tranquillement et excellente dans son genre.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 My Bottom Line:
This syrupy monsters overstated cassis fruitiness, low carbonation and exceedingly sweet candied nature is simply impossible to drink with more than tiny sips. On pancakes though...

Further Personal Perceptions:
-There is no head atop the opaque brown red.
-The overwhelming cough syrup impressions got on my nerves quite quickly.
-The sweet fruitiness and candy character become akin to rosewater, somehow. Something I would not think of drinking, by the way.
-Alcohol warmth is not overdone, but there is so much caramel and candy sweetness...
-Roastiness flies by...and away. Scared, surely.

Bottle.

12 oz bottle.  Murky purple with a ring of small bubbles and a slick.  Nose is currants, toffee, berries, moldy wood and gummi bears.  Cough syrup body with a tang and unfortunately the taste is the same.  Grape soda, cherry cough drops, over-ripe peaches, limeade and wood alcohol.  KREs evil twin.

Draft @ Kuhnhenn:  Call it immaturity, but I find it overwhelmingly coincidental that with a simple letter alteration, Cassis quickly becomes Catpiss, and even further coincidental that this beer smells like a neglected, stray cat in heat.  That olfactory assault aside, it tastes like fire, or my first attempt and failure at making hairy buffalo in a 17-gallon trash can.  It is like liquid PMS; just nasty.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Bottled. A deep red beer with a rim of tan head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of fruits and black currant, cherries, and chocolate - reminds me of Mon Cherie chocolates. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of berries and fruit - especieally cherries and black currant. The alcohol burns on the inside of the lips. Thanks yespr for sharing.

Draft at Kuhnhenns. Pours a deep dark purple with a small quickly disappearing tan head (no lacing). Aroma is filled with black currant, grapes, alcohol, and other fruits. Flavor is huge filled with the taste of black currant and grapes mainly but just a hint of the alcohol. Mouthfeel is dry almost wine like with a warming feel in the belly as it goes down. An excellent sipping beer, recommended to all that have the chance to experience it.
12oz bottle.  Deep cola appearance.  Big cassis aroma.  Flavors of sweet cherries as well as a distinct cassis character.  Lots of burn, big heat, high ABV.

12oz. bottle, with another thanks to yjb (Yaniv) for the great Kuhnhenn hookup!  Pours a clear cola brown with a minimal tan head, no lacing.  Aroma is ripe dark fruit juice, with blackberry, currant, and plum, along with light roast and chocolate.  Flavor starts with more dark fruit juice, has a strongly medicinal middle, and then finishes with a lingering roasty chocolate; very warming, and almost hot.  A unique sipper for sure, but overall its disappointing.

[What a treat  thanks a million yespr] Hazy brown with tiny off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with notes of black currant, caramel and roasted malt. Sweet flavor with black currant , caramel, chocolate and toasted malt. Ends sweet with waming alcohol. Very well balanced.

4-5-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to hoppymeal and Ibrew2or3 

Murky thin brown with no head.  Smell is big of fruit rollups and booze.  Flavor is very fruity and big on alcohol.  It is very warming and "hot" - the alcohol takes center stage in this one.  I am not a fan of fruit beers - and this is a bold representation of it.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008 12 fl oz bottle, trade with Brad - thanks. Pours golden deep redish with a fully diminished white head. Chocolate and black berry aroma. Flavour is dense black berry, chocolate and rising liqourice note. Dense roasted malt base. Solid alcohol presence. Light wooden note too. Lingering chocolate flavoured finish. Very dense and yet smooth. Goes into a light reappearing black berry flavoured far finish.

Botella, mis gracias al señor Jesper/yespr. Pours a bit hazy deep brown colour with a quite short lasting head. Sweet quite fruity black currant alco aroma. Good mouthfeel. Quite sweet and lovely fruity lightly bitter alco black currant flavour. The strongest and the best fruit beer I have ever had. More of that por favore!

Bottle. [thank you, Yespr]
[at Yeprs tuesday tasting]
[my 2800th rating]
Pours deep red with a small film head - disappears almost instantly. Aroma is kinda soft, has a stunning amount of black currants, bordering on chocolate, softly vinious and some liqourice. Lovely oily mouthfeel with just a little carbonation. Flavour is super fruity, black currants, vinious, sticky, liqourice and wonderfully warming. Best brew in the house this day!

Bottle. [Courtesy of yespr, thanks buddy]  Small fizzy off-white head that mostly diminished. Oily like lacework. Muddy mahogany colour. Aroma of black currant, liquorish, complex fruit and dried fruit, very vinous, almost turning into chocolate. Over the palate came warming alcohol, strong berries and again black currant. Very full-bodied with a soft carbonation and light dry and strong alcoholic texture. Heavy sweet flavour with mild bitter notes. Lingering black currant and warming alcohol finish.

Bottle:  Deep plum in color with a tiny, soon to be gone beige head.  Aroma is very berrylike and sweet.  Boisenberry preserves come to mind.  Taste is a fruity sour with lots of malt.  A pleasant warming takes effect in the trailer.  Ahh 16.5% ABV.  No friggen wonder!  Still, the flavor is kind of muddled.  I think Ill pass on this one.  Thanks jjpm74 for this bonus brew!

12oz bottle shared with Axilla.  Thanks. Poured  brown with solid hues of amber.  No head present. Aroma of currants, berries, sweet dark fruit sugars, and alcohol. Taste is sweet with currants, dark fruits, licorice,  and it comes in strong with alcohol burning.  Mellowed nicely, and I really enjoyed this for a sipper.  Its interesting to see the ratings on this one.  Its obvious you either love it or hate it.  (Except for me... Im somewhere in between)

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 A- Pours a murky brown color with a small off white head which fades quickly.

S- Smell definitely has cassis in it, very sweet, grapey, with hints of assorted fruits (possibly blackberries?)

T- Taste is sweet but almost instantely the alcohol hits you in the mouth, very warming, cassis, caramel, roasty flavors.

M- Thick with a good amount of carbonation.

D- This obviously isnt a session beer and it isnt meant to be. I love how kuhnhenn is so in your face with the alcohol as if to say "If you dont like it screw you". They balance things so perfectly it just makes you smile more and more with every sip. Everything comes together sublimely with this brew.

Bottle from footbalm. Thanks Eric! I actually liked this one, so you dont owe me one man! Muddy auburn with no head. An awesome aroma of currant, berry, grape, candy. Very nice fruity aroma. The flavor is an interesting mix of grape, raisin, currant, and berry with chocolate and  light roast, as well as burning. A little medicinal and cough syrup like, but not too much. For 16.5%, I was expecting this to kick my ass, but I have had hotter beers at lower alcohol. Definitely a sipper. It will put me asleep, I hope I can wake up tomorrow!

12oz bottle, no date (though I think Dec. 2007 was the last release) from many people, most recently goryshkewych--thanks George.  Cloudy reddish brown  at the edges, opaque otherwise with a small beige head that faded to a ring quickly.  Tons of fruit and berries in the aroma--raspberries, currants, concord grapes and strawberries--with some sweet Tootsie Roll chocolate in the background with faint cough syrup and alcohol hinting at its strength.  The flavor was much the same with fruits and berries dominating with Tootsie Roll.  Not overly sweet, as I wouldve thought, as the acidity from the fruits help try to balance it out.  This still comes across as pretty hot, but at 16.5% and less than a year old, what wouldnt?  Thankfully it didnt seem too NyQuil/cough syrup/medicine cabinet-like at all.  Dry finish with low bitterness (peaked around a 2).    Full syrupy body with low carbonation.  Its unfortunate that Eric didnt enjoy this at all--this must be a love it/hate it beer.  That said, I almost loved it.  Glad I have a few more to drink and share!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Nose is absolute heaven, absolute heaven but this taste like a toxic chemical was accidently dumped into the batch. This smells so damn fantastic but tastes like a cough syrup experiment gone awray.The aroma from this is wonderful but the flavor is like berries in kerosene. I mean, it isnt the worse beer I have ever had but is sure is the worst fruit beer I have ever had, oh shit, maybe not, I almost forgot about those nasty-ass Dogfish fruit beers. I shouldna traded any of these, sorry guys, I owe you one.

Bottles courtesy of hoppymeal, and Ibrew2or3.  Thanks!
Pours a rich brownish muddy maroon color.  Smell is strong and very aromatic concentrated berries and some alcohol.  Taste is rich, sweet berry/grape cassis flavor and alcohol.  Somewhat medicinal and liquier like.  Warming.  Interesting and good in very small increments but can quickly become too much.

I have been holding on to this one for a while 
Thanks to kryptic for supplying me this one 
once you pry the cap of the fruit aroma fills the room 

The bottle poured into a sniffer produced a small amount of off white head on top of a black body
The head goes a way leaving a ring of lace around the glass 

Aroma is tons and tons of fruit currants blackberries and grapes wow it smells great 

The flavor takes awhile to grow on you. The fruit (raspberries and currants) is somewhat overwhelming. The mouthfeel is so thick that this is a must sip beer if you can call it a beer. It is sweet but there is some bitter to it as well as alcohol warmth 

I think you could split this bottle with a friend and it would be enough for both of you. It is a wonderful brew but it can become overwhelming if you try and rush it. It reminded me more of a cordial than a beer I am glad I went with a sniffer for this one

Date: 03/22/2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party

Appearance: clear dark brown, fine tan head, layers of viscous liquid, 
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma with a dark caramel sweetness, 
Flavor: rich sweet fruity black current flavor, lots of dark caramel sweetness, light tartness balances out the sweetness, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 17/20
Rating: 4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: ***+/4

12oz bottle pours deep dark amber with almost no head sustaining only just an atom thin ring. The aroma is full bold and nearly bludgeoning the olfactory senses with fresh fruit flesh from cherries, black currents and kiwi. This is certainly not some simple syrupy extract addition. I can smell this from a couple of feet away too. In fact I could smell it the next morning even though I rinsed my glass. A long draw of the aroma pulls up some hotness on the nose. The flavor begins with rich sweet cherries, black currents and a mild kiwi note. Then the flesh of the fruit is added to the flavor before the dark fruity esters, mild caramel and chocolate malts of the base beer emerge. Yum. As the finish approaches the cherry and black current sweet fruitiness return carrying a faint fruit tart sourness. Faint caramelized malts and faint sourness head deep into the after taste. Wow, great experience.

Bottle shared by B2K at Pauls. Dark brown color with some red highlights and virtually no head. Strong fruit aroma of currants and strawberries, with a big alcohol nose that when combined reminds me of cough syrup. Flavor starts off very sweet with the currants at the forefront before turning somewhat tart and finishing with a big alcoholic wallop. Really didnt taste like cough syrup, but could not get the thought out of my head that I was drinking Robitussin. I am not a big fan of currants, so it was no surprise that I really did not like this beer.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Mostly transparent, cedar bark brown colored puor with a wispy head of off-white.  

Intense cassis nose, dripping with fruit.  Amazing, albeit a bit one-dimensional.  Juicy black currants dripping 

with fructose sugars.  Medium bodied, thinly carbonated mouthfeel.  Black currant fruit flavors appear briefly on 

the front of the palate before succumbing to a medicinal grape sudafed flavor that completely ruins the beer.  

Tons of medicinal, green Nyquil flavors.  Lots of cassis initially, but way too much syrupy medicine.  How can a 

beer that smells this good taste so bad?

12oz bottle via trade with hoppymeal, got another from kmweaver, this is from derek though.  Pours black with a thin tan ring.  Smells like grape juice with a hint of booze.  Taste is sweet syrupy boozy with a hint of bitterness.  This is a pretty big beer, which I guess I should have expected.  A little hot but at 16.5% I cant expect it to be much different as there isnt much age on this.  Its a drinkable sipper.

Sampled at Tampa tasting, courtesy Degarth.  Darkish amber color, light sparse white head.  Aroma is a blast of currants, seems like there should be seeds rolling around in the glass.  Nice thick texture.  High in alcohol, but mostly avoids cough syrup-like character.  The cassis does a nice job of mellowing out the alcohol.

Murky reddish-purple.  Big cassis with a tart, malty, slightly vinegary brown ale background.  Somewhat stiff.  A bit too much alcohol for the palate but its good for the body as it cuts through an otherwise syrupy black currant.  Decent brew.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown body with ruby-hued hints at the edges and encircled by a ring of off-white bubbles. Here goes nothing.

Smell: Holy moly, you can smell the black currants the second the cap is lifted from the bottle. No doubt Im in for a treat. Pure cassis, babies!

Taste: Dark malts bolstered by a strong sweetness. The flavor is dominated by the concentrated, liqueur-like black currant taste. Faint hint of roast, a touch of chocolate. A lip-licking tartness from the fruit comes out to temper the sweetness. Finishes leaving a lightly tart aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied. Medium carbonation. Thick, tongue-coating mouthfeel. Wonderfully warming.

Drinkability: Sporting an intense, yet refined cassis liqueur flavor, this beverage is best suited to a post-dinner sipper or instances of plotting intriques. I will always adore Kuhnhenn for brewing this beer, as well as others like their Raspberry Eisbock, Fourth Dementia, and Imperial Stout. Dont care what they churn out in the future; theyll forever have my awe because of these beers.

But thats just me.

Damn this beer will smack you in the face. But my god its a good one. A brown appearance with no head. Aroma is cassis, raisins, and alcohol. The flavor is quite sweet and warming with cassis and some apple detectable. The mouthfeel is very syrupy. This is like drinking brandy. Which isnt a bad thing BTW. This is a good dessert beer. One of my favorites of the evening!

Tap at HDG. Hazy copper in color with a little off white head. Sweet fruity malty aroma. Caramel dark fruity notes. Malty and sweet flavor. Cherries, and apple notes.  Finish is fruity. Tart tasting. Very nice beer. Very drinkable. It doesn taste like its 16.5 percent. 
The alcohol is hidden well. Very enjoyable.

Pours a deep amber brown color with a quickly disappearing slight tan head.  Aroma is sweet grape/black currant fruit and some caramel.  Flavor is sweet fruity black currant fruit, malt, and a sweet fruity alcohol finish.

Tap at Hop Devil: Pours a muddy burgundy with a fading head. Very pungent nose of blackberry jam, candied cassis and chambord liqueur. Huge aroma, but pretty simple. Slick body with a rich, sweet flavor. Lots of sweet and sticky maple, fruit preserves (cassis/grape jelly). The later flavors make it what it is, giving off a black currant richness and some dark/toasted toffee in the finish. A bit over the top, but still a tasty concoction in moderation.

Courtesy of Degarth. Thank you, sir.
